description: A major Romano-British religious complex on a promontory overlooking the River Severn. Coin evidence apparently suggests that the cult continued into the early 5th CE, even though the temple superstructure seems to have collapsed by 370 CE.
bibliography: Bathurst, W. H., and C. W. King. Roman Antiquities at Lydney Park, 1879.
Casey, and Hoffmann. “Excavations at the Roman Temple at Lydney Park, Gloucestershire in 1980 and 1981.” Antiquaries Journal 79 (1999).
Martyn, Blick, Brindle, and et al. “Lydney Park (Gloucestershire).” The Rural Settlement of Roman Britain: an online resource, 2015. https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449.
Richmond, I. A. In Roman Britain, 139, 1955.
Scott-Garrett. “Roman Iron Mine in Lydney Park (1959).” Trans Bristol and Gloucestershire Archaeological Society 78 (1959).
Smith, Alex. “The Fate of Pagan Temples in South-East Britain.” In Ritual Landsacpes of South-East Britain, edited by David Rudling, 2008.
Wheeler, R. E. M. Report on the Excavations ... in Lydney Park, 1932.
